questions.text:
A middle-aged woman presented with redness and itching over the nipple of her left breast. Histopathological findings of the lesion are shown below. Which of the following statements correctly describes the typical cells seen here?

 DCIS- Ductal carcinoma in situ, LCIS- Lobular carcinoma in situ.

choices.text: ER negative, malignant cells arising from underlying DCIS
ER positive, benign cells arising from underlying DCIS
ER positive, malignant cells arising from underlying LCIS
ER negative, benign cells arising from underlying LCIS

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image showing Paget's cells (malignant cells with abundant pale cytoplasm and pleomorphic nuclei) are suggestive of Paget's disease of the nipple. These cells are ER-negative, malignant cells arising from underlying DCIS.

Paget's disease of the nipple is a rare form of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). The characteristic Paget's cells are scattered individually throughout the squamous epithelium. They do not breach the basement membrane but extend via the lactiferous sinuses into the nipple skin.

The following images show Paget's cells that do not breach the basement membrane.

It presents as a unilateral erythematous eruption with a scale crust. A palpable mass is seen in about half the patients with this disease.

The underlying carcinomas are usually poorly differentiated, ER-negative, and overexpress HER2. The prognosis of Paget's disease depends on the features of the underlying carcinoma.

Paget's disease may mimic the following conditions:

  • Eczema (clinical appearance) - Can be differentiated by the presence of malignant cells on biopsy.
  • Superficial spreading melanoma (histological appearance) - Paget's cells are PAS-positive and diastase resistant, unlike melanoma cells.

Note: Paget's disease of the bone is a distinct condition that results in abnormal bone metabolism due to osteoclastic overactivity.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with backache. Urine examination revealed nephrotic-range proteinuria with Bence-Jones proteins. Laboratory reports showed hypercalcemia. The image below shows the appearance of a renal biopsy specimen stained with Congo red and visualized under polarized light. Accumulation of which fibril protein will majorly be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient has multiple myeloma. The major fibril protein accumulated in this patient is amyloid light chain (AL).

The above clinical scenario of backache, proteinuria with Bence-Jones protein, hypercalcemia are suggestive of multiple myeloma. The image showing a Congo red–stained biopsy specimen with apple-green birefringence under polarized microscopy is indicative of amyloid accumulation in the organ. In multiple myeloma, the amyloid is made from the light chain of immunoglobulins (chiefly λ type). 

Amyloidosis refers to extracellular deposits of fibrillar proteins. The abnormal fibrils are obtained by the aggregation of misfolded proteins. The fibrillar deposits bind to proteoglycans and glycosaminoglycans, including heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate, and plasma proteins, notably serum amyloid P component (SAP). Amyloid is an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance.

Microscopy:

All types of amyloid deposits are made up of continuous, nonbranching fibrils and are demonstrated on electron microscopy. A characteristic cross-β-pleated sheet conformation is visualized on x-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy. The stain used for amyloid deposits is Congo red staining. It imparts pink to red color to the amyloid under ordinary light. Under polarized microscopy, Congo red-stained amyloid shows apple-green birefringence.

Other options:

Option A -  The fibrillar protein amyloid β2 microglobulin (Aβ2M) is accumulated in hemodialysis-associated amyloidosis in chronic renal failure.

Option B -The fibrillar protein amyloid-associated (AA) is accumulated in secondary systemic amyloidosis and familial Mediterranean fever.

Option D - The fibrillar protein amyloid transthyretin (ATTR) is accumulated in the mutated form in familial amyloidotic polyneuropathies and in an unmutated form in systemic senile amyloidosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is being investigated for long-standing complaints of heartburn. An endoscopic biopsy reveals mucosal atrophy of the gastric fundus sparing the antrum, accompanied by infiltration of lymphocytes and macrophages in gastric glands. Serum anti-parietal cell antibodies are positive. She also has had vitiligo for 10 years. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presentation of heartburn with biopsy findings of antral sparing gastric mucosal atrophy, anti-parietal cell antibody positivity (sensitive for pernicious anemia), and autoimmune disease association (vitiligo) point towards the diagnosis of autoimmune gastritis.

Various features of autoimmune gastritis include:

  • Pernicious anemia (anti-intrinsic factor positivity is specific)
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency and megaloblastic anemia 
  • Hypergastrinemia 
  • Reduce serum pepsinogen
  • Achlorhydria

Other options:

Option A: Helicobacter pylori gastritis is antral predominant and causes gastric atrophy. It has a large number of plasma cells in the superficial lamina propria along with lymphocytes microscopically. It is also not associated with any antibodies and causes patchy atrophy.

Option B: Lymphocytic gastritis affects the entire stomach and is characterized by microscopic findings of intraepithelial T lymphocyte infiltration. It is associated with celiac disease.

Option D: Granulomatous gastritis is characterized by the presence of granulomas microscopically. Narrowing and rigidity of the gastric antrum are also seen. It is associated with conditions like Crohn’s disease and sarcoidosis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with an abdominal mass. Ultrasonography reveals the right ovary size to be 15 cm x 10 cm. Serum LDH was raised. The surgically resected specimen is positive for the immunohistochemistry markers KIT, OCT3, OCT4, and NANOG. Which of the following tumor markers is characteristic of this tumor?
questions.solution:
An ovarian mass in a 20-year-old associated with raised LDH and immunohistochemistry markers KIT, OCT3, OCT4, and NANOG is suggestive of dysgerminoma. This tumor is characterized by elevated placental alkaline phosphatase, LDH, and beta HCG.

Dysgerminoma is a germ cell tumor that corresponds to seminoma of the testis and is accountable for 3-5% of ovarian tumors. It is a solid ovarian tumor with an average age of presentation of 20 years.

Other options:

Option B: CA 19-9 is secreted from ductal cells in the pancreas, biliary cells, and epithelial cells in the stomach, colon, and uterus. This marker is characteristically elevated in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma. It can also be raised in gastrointestinal tumors and epithelial tumors of the ovary.

Option C: Dysgerminoma tumor cells neither secrete estrogen nor testosterone.

Option D: Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is elevated in patients with mucinous ovarian tumors.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presenting with blood in stool has the following examination findings. Her father had similar complaints at the age of 10 and was recently diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. The patient's biopsy samples are obtained after a colonoscopy. What are the most likely histological changes to be seen?
questions.solution:
A young child with blood in stools, positive family history, and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation as shown in the image is suggestive of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. Hamartomous polyps with normal epithelium are seen in this condition.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition that is characterized by the formation of multiple hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract (small intestine, colon, and stomach) and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation. The hyperpigmentation typically appears as dark blue to brown macules on the lips, nostrils, buccal mucosa, palmar surfaces of the hands, genitalia, and perianal region. This rare syndrome presents at a median age of 11 years. This condition is associated with an increased risk of malignancies which include cancers of the stomach and small intestines, colon, pancreas, breast, and lungs.

The histopathological findings of the polyps reveal an arborizing network (freely branching) of glands that are lined by the normal intestinal epithelium, as seen in the image below: 


Other options:

Both ulcerative colitis (option A) and Crohn's disease (option C) can present with blood in stools, however, they have a bimodal median age of presentation (2nd-4th decades of life and 7th-9th decades of life). 

Option A - Pseudopolyps with submucosal crypt abscesses are the histopathological findings seen in ulcerative colitis. It is a form of inflammatory bowel disease. It involves the entirety of the colon (pancolitis) and presents with bloody mucoid diarrhea and cramping abdominal pain.

Here is an image showing crypt abscesses limited to the mucosa and submucosa as seen in ulcerative colitis:


Option C - Noncaseating granulomas with transmural ulcers and skip lesions are histopathological findings as seen in Crohn's disease. 

It is also a form of inflammatory bowel disease that commonly involves the terminal ileum but can affect any portion of the GI tract. Patients usually present with iron deficiency anemia and sporadic attacks of mild diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain.

Here is an image showing noncaseating granulomas as seen in Crohn's disease:


Option D - Adenomatous polyps with epithelial dysplasia are seen in neoplastic polyps. The patients usually present in adulthood.

These can range from small and pedunculated to large and sessile. It is a premalignant pathology that has a high risk of progression to colonic adenocarcinoma. Types of neoplastic/adenomatous polyps include tubular, tubulovillous, and villous polyps. Common histological findings include markers of epithelial dysplasia such as nuclear hyperchromasia, elongation, and stratification. 

The image below shows tubular and villous adenomas seen in neoplastic polyps:

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

 

Histologic image showing the characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by normal-appearing intestinal epithelium:

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with Ewing sarcoma with ESWR1 gene mutation. The technique shown in the image was performed to confirm the diagnosis. At what stage of the cell cycle is this test performed?
questions.solution:
The technique shown in the image is Fluorescent In Situ Hybridisation (FISH) demonstrating a positive EWSR1 gene rearrangement, characteristic of Ewing sarcoma. It is carried out during the interphase stage of the cell cycle. Metaphase cells can also demonstrate this. 

The fused region denoted by yellow corresponds to a normal intact gene, while a split signal pattern showing separate red and green signals is indicative of EWSR1 gene rearrangement.

Fluorescent In Situ Hybridisation (FISH) is a simple technique for the detection of specific genetic information on morphologically intact tissue using fluorescent probes. FISH can be performed on prenatal samples, peripheral blood cells, touch preparations from cancer biopsies, and even fixed archival tissue sections. It is used to detect

  • numeric abnormalities of chromosomes (aneuploidy)
  • subtle microdeletions and rearrangements.
  • complex translocations that are not demonstrable by routine karyotyping
  • gene amplification (e.g., HER2 in breast cancer or NMYC amplification in neuroblastomas)

Related Pearl: Fluorescent In Situ Hybridisation (FISH)

It is a simple technique for the detection of specific genetic information on a morphologically intact tissue using fluorescent probes.

The fluorescent probes are added to cells usually arrested in the metaphase stage of cell division (when every chromosome is separately).

Types of FISH:

1) Chromosomal painting: Each chromosome is identified by using a different colour of the fluorescent probe, however, each chromosome does not have a unique colour. Since the fluorescent dyes are limited.

2) Multicolour FISH: 23 distinct fluorescent colours made by mixing 5 fluorophores. Thus each chromosome is identified by a unique colour. It is also known as spectral karyotyping (SKY). It offers various advantages such as

  • Detects structural and numeric abnormalities in chromosomes.
  • Detects gene amplification and subtle microdeletions
  • Maps a newly isolated gene to its correct chromosomal loci

However, this process requires prior knowledge of the genes and chromosomes.

3) Interphase FISH: It is a rapid procedure of FISH, wherein growing cells are not needed. It is used in prenatal diagnosis and in tumour diagnosis.

The image shown is of a Multicolor FISH also known as Spectral karyotyping with a unique colour to each chromosome pair.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents with painless generalized lymphadenopathy and weakness. The biopsy findings of H&E staining and immunohistochemistry for BCL2 are given in the images below. The results of immunophenotyping of the cells are as follows: CD19+, CD20+, CD10+, and CD5-. What is the translocation seen in this disease?

H&E: Hematoxyline and eosin
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of follicular lymphoma. The majority of follicular lymphomas have the characteristic t(14;18) translocation.

Follicular lymphoma presents in middle age with no sex predilection. The most common presenting symptom is painless generalized lymphadenopathy. A lymph node biopsy is adequate for the diagnosis of follicular lymphoma. Immunophenotyping of the cells showing CD19, CD20, CD10, BCL2 positive, and CD5 negative is suggestive that the cells originate from the germinal center.

This chromosomal rearrangement results in the overexpression of BCL2 protein, which is an inhibitor of apoptosis that contributes to cell survival.

On histopathology, the lymph nodes exhibit a nodular or nodular and diffuse growth pattern. Two cell types are predominantly present in varying proportions: 

  • Centrocytes (small cleaved cells) - small cells with a cleaved nucleus and scant cytoplasm
  • Centroblasts - large cells with open nuclear chromatin, several nucleoli, and modest amounts of cytoplasm

In most cases, there is a majority of centrocytes.

Other options:

Option B: t(9;22) results in Philadelphia chromosome, which causes chronic myeloid leukemia.

Option C: t(8;14) is seen in Burkitt lymphoma.

Option D: t(11,14) is seen in mantle cell lymphoma.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presented to the OPD with an asymmetrical nevus with irregular margins and variegated colour on her arm. Recently, the nevus had become pruritic. The histopathological examination of the lesion is shown below. Which stain would have been used on the biopsy specimen in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical features suggest a diagnosis of melanocytic nevus. In the histopathological examination, the Masson Fontana stain is used which is used for detecting melanin (seen as a dark or black pigmented area) as shown in the above image.

Stains used for melanin:

Masson Fontana silver stain: The ammoniacal silver stains melanin black. It is also used to stain argentaffin granules, which are normally present in endocrine cells in duodenal mucosa and pathologically seen in carcinoid syndromes.

Melanin:

  • In general, melanin is considered as the only endogenous brown-black pigment present in the hair, skin, retina, iris, and certain parts of the central nervous system (as neuromelanin). Pathologically, it may be found in skin tumors like melanomas.
  • However, another black-colored endogenous pigment called homogentisic acid may be seen in alkaptonuria, where the pigment is deposited in the skin, connective tissue, and cartilage; this pigmentation is known as ochronosis.

DOPA-oxidase method: It is the most specific method for staining melanin. The stain works on the principle that the DOPA substrate is acted upon by DOPA-oxidase in the melanin-producing cells which produce a brownish-black deposit. 

Schmorl’s method: Stains melanin blue-green.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man with a chronic history of smoking is diagnosed with lung carcinoma. The tumour is located centrally and CT-guided biopsy reveals the following histopathology. Which of the following is not a marker of this type of carcinoma?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and the histological image showing the basophilic staining of the vessel wall (Azzopardi effect) are suggestive of a small cell carcinoma of the lung. Chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56 are the markers for small cell lung carcinoma.P40 is a marker of squamous cell carcinoma

This tumor originates from neuroendocrine progenitor cells (Kulchitsky cells), which are present in the lining bronchial epithelium.

Histology of small cell lung carcinoma shows clusters of small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern), and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli. The cells are round, oval, or spindle-shaped, and nuclear molding is prominent.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with increased fatigue, low-grade fevers, and night sweats. Physical examination reveals several small, rubbery, mobile, non-tender supraclavicular lymph nodes. The lymph node biopsy findings are shown in the image below. Immunophenotyping shows CD15+, CD30+, and PAX5+. Activation of which of the following factors occurs in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the image showing Reed-Sternberg cells are suggestive of a diagnosis of Hodgkin's lymphoma. Activation of the transcription factor NF-κB is a common event in classical Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL).

NF-κB may be activated by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection. EBV+ tumor cells express latent membrane protein-1 (LMP-1), a protein encoded by the EBV genome that transmits signals that upregulate NF-κB. Activation of NF-κB may occur in EBV tumors as a result of the acquired loss-of-function mutations in TNF alpha-induced protein 3 (TNFAIP3). (Option D)

Activation of NF-κB by EBV or other mechanisms rescues “crippled” germinal center B cells that cannot express Igs from apoptosis, eventually leading to the formation of Reed-Sternberg cells. TNF α, IL-10, and TGF beta are involved in cross-talk between Reed-Sternberg cells and other normal cells in classical forms of Hodgkin's lymphoma. (Option A and B)

Reed-Sternberg cell: It is a giant cell. It has a classic owl-eyed appearance due to the presence of a symmetric or mirror-image bilobed nucleus with prominent nucleoli surrounded by a clear space.

Clinical features of Hodgkin's lymphoma - Typical presentation involves lymphadenopathy/ mass with B symptoms, which include fever, night sweats, and weight loss.

Diagnosis - Requires microscopic findings and immunophenotyping findings to correlate. Microscopy of lymph nodes shows the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to your clinic with erythematous skin lesions covered with white plaques on the extensor aspects of his elbows. A skin biopsy reveals the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation and the skin biopsy findings are suggestive of psoriasis vulgaris.

Image A shows epidermal parakeratosis, increased epidermal thickening-acanthosis, absent granular layer, and regular downward elongation of rete redges. Image 'B' shows the presence of neutrophil aggregates in the stratum corneum, known as Munro microabscess. These findings are suggestive of psoriasis.

Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory dermatosis with an autoimmune basis affecting the skin (mostly elbows, knees, scalp, etc.). The typical lesions are pink-salmon-colored plaques covered by loosely adherent white plaques. Early lesions may be dominated by inflammation marked by erythema and small pustules. Additional microscopic findings may be dilated, tortuous blood vessels in the dermal papilla.


Other options:

Option A: Pemphigus vulgaris microscopically has acantholysis which is the dissolution of intracellular bridges that connect squamous epithelial cells with basal cells forming suprabasal clefts and blisters. Basal cells stay attached to the basement membrane but separate from one another, resembling a row of tombstones.


Option B: Mycosis fungoides microscopically has atypical cells forming band-like aggregates in the superficial dermis and epidermis as clusters, known as Pautrier microabscesses.


Option D: Lichen planus microscopically has a dense infiltration of Langerhans cells along the dermo-epidermal junction with 'saw toothing' of the rete redges. Additionally, anucleate necrotic basal cells may be incorporated into the inflamed papillary dermis where they are referred to as colloid or civette bodies with acanthosis of the epidermis, thickening of the granular layer, and hyperkeratosis.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy with a white reflex came to the OPD. A histopathological examination showed the following picture and a tumor involving more than half of the retina. What is the most common mode of spread of this tumor?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of retinoblastoma, and direct invasion is the most common mode of spread of retinoblastoma.

Retinoblastoma is the most common intraocular malignancy in children associated with mutations in the RB1 gene at chromosome 13q14. 

It arises from the neurosensory retina. It is a proliferation of neural cells that have failed to evolve normally. Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children. Tumors are composed of small basophilic cells (retinoblasts), with large hyperchromatic nuclei and scanty cytoplasm.

The child is usually brought to the surgeon on account of a peculiar yellowish-white reflex from the pupil, sometimes called leukocoria or amaurotic cat’s eye. Other modes of presentation include a convergent or divergent squint, cataract, buphthalmos, hypopyon, or proptosis. If left untreated, retinoblastoma runs through the following stages:

  • The quiescent stage - lasts from 6 months to a year.
  • The glaucomatous stage - Results in the enlargement of the globe, with apparent or real proptosis. Pain is severe during this stage but is relieved when the tumor bursts through the sclera.  
  • The stage of extraocular extension.
  • The stage of metastasis.

Histopathology of the tumor shows small round cells with large nuclei. Microscopic features of a well-differentiated tumor include Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific to retinoblastoma), Homer-Wright rosettes, pseudorosettes, and fleurettes formation. Areas of necrosis and calcification can also be seen.

The most common mode of spread of retinoblastoma is through direct invasion. It can invade the optic nerve and spread to the brain, or it can also directly spread to the sclera or orbit.

Treatment typically involves chemotherapy plus focal therapy. Vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide are the choice of drugs for chemotherapy. Focal therapy includes cryotherapy, laser photocoagulation, thermotherapy, plaque radiotherapy, and external beam radiotherapy.
 
Enucleation is done when the tumor involves more than half of the retina, optic nerve involvement, glaucoma, and anterior chamber involvement.

questions.text: An 81-year-old lady presented with the following raised lesion which has gotten itchy. It is scaly but does not produce bleeding on itching. A short course of steroids is given but no improvement is seen. Biopsy revealed full-thickness epidermal dysplasia with loss of epithelial polarity. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and biopsy findings suggest a likely diagnosis of Bowen's disease

Bowen’s disease is an intraepidermal squamous cell carcinoma. It is characterized by a persistent, solitary,  non‐elevated, red, scaly, or crusted plaque with a small potential for invasive malignancy.

It usually grows progressively but sometimes undergoes spontaneous partial resolution. It is commonly seen in patients more than 60 years of age and predominantly seen in women. Human Papilloma Virus 16 infection is associated with it.

It can occur anywhere, but it occurs more in the head and neck region.  Histologically, it is characterized by full-thickness epidermal dysplasia with loss of polarity.

Initially, patients present with a small, red, and slightly scaly area, which gradually enlarges in an irregular fashion. The margins of the lesions are slightly raised with the surface is usually flat. Bowen disease on perianal skin carries a higher risk of invasion and recurrence. Management includes cryotherapy, curettage, topical 5% 5-fluorouracil, 5% imiquimod cream. 

Other options:

Option A- Plaque psoriasis is the most common clinical type of psoriasis. Psoriatic plaques are symmetrical, well defined, and erythematous distributed over the elbow, knees, and lower back. On removal of the slivery-white scales, it shows pinpoint bleeding spots called the Auspitz sign. Histology shows parakeratosis, spongiform pustules, microabscesses with the neutrophil collection, and tortuous dilated papillary capillaries.

Option B- Discoid dermatitis has large multiple plaques and mainly presents with pruritus. Histology shows parakeratosis, intracellular edema, eosinophils, and exocytosis of lymphocytes. Most of the cases show improvement with corticosteroids. 

Option D- Malignant melanoma is the malignant transformation of melanocytes that are derived from neural crest cells. it is commonly found in patients younger than 55 years. The characteristics of melanoma are:

  • Asymmetry
  • Border irregularity
  • Color variations, especially red, white, and blue tones in a brown or black lesion
  • Diameter greater than 6 mm
  • Evolution

Histopathology shows individual melanoma cells which are larger than normal melanocytes. They have large nuclei with irregular contours, chromatin is characteristically clumped at the periphery of the nuclear membrane with prominent red eosinophilic nucleoli.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient on oral contraceptives presented with abdominal pain and increasing abdominal girth for the past five days. Physical examination revealed hepatomegaly and ascites. A liver biopsy showed severe centrilobular congestion and necrosis and organized thrombi in the major hepatic veins. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and histopathological findings are suggestive of hepatic vein thrombosis or Budd-Chiari syndrome.

Obstruction of the major hepatic veins due to thrombosis leads to a condition known as Budd-Chiari syndrome. It presents with a triad of abdominal pain, hepatomegaly and ascites. The damage to the hepatic tissue is a result of increased intrahepatic blood pressure. It principally affects young women with an underlying hypercoagulable state such as deficiency of protein C, S or anti-thrombin. Oral contraceptive intake increases the risk of hepatic vein thrombosis. Hepatic vein thrombosis is also associated with myeloproliferative neoplasms like polycythemia vera, antiphospholipid antibody syndrome, paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria and hepatocellular carcinoma.

Grossly the liver is swollen, red-purple in color and has a tense capsule. Microscopically, there may be areas of hemorrhage alternating with areas of preserved parenchyma. Centrilobular congestion and necrosis is seen. The major hepatic veins contain thrombi and they may get organized into the wall of the vessel.

Other options:

Option B: Metastatic liver disease - It typically presents with multiple liver lesions and is not associated with centrilobular congestion, organized thrombi in the major hepatic veins, or the clinical picture described in the scenario. 

Option C: Primary biliary cholangitis, previously called primary biliary cirrhosis, is an autoimmune disease associated with inflammatory destruction of small- and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts. It usually presents with fatigue, pruritus, and jaundice. 

Option D: Secondary biliary cirrhosis refers to inflammation, fibrosis, and scarring, secondary to chronic obstruction of the extrahepatic bile ducts.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with painless, gross hematuria. He was evaluated for the same, and a cystoprostatectomy was done. The specimen image is shown below. Which among the following is not a risk factor for his condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows fungating growth from the bladder wall involving the entire bladder; the likely diagnosis would be bladder cancer. Benzene is a risk factor for leukemia and not bladder carcinoma.

Cigarette smoking is the main etiological factor. Other risk factors include exposure to aniline dyes like benzidine and naphthylamine, schistosomiasis, and cyclophosphamide. The majority of it is transitional cell carcinoma (90%), with squamous and adenocarcinoma being rare forms.

Painless, gross hematuria is the most common symptom that is indicative of a bladder carcinoma until proven otherwise. Subsequent clots and urinary retention can occur. Increased frequency and discomfort during urination may be seen. It can lead to pelvic pain due to extravesical spread, loin pain due to hydronephrosis, and suprapubic pain if the nerve is involved.

Management is as follows:

  • Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer - Endoscopic resection and intravesical instillations of mitomycin C/ epirubicin, immunotherapy with regular intravesical instillations of Bacille Calmette-Guerin (BCG)
  • Muscle invasive bladder cancer - Radical cystectomy along with urinary diversion procedure and lymph node dissection, with/without neoadjuvant chemotherapy

questions.text: A  primigravida was brought to the emergency department with the sudden onset of fever, altered mental status, confusion, and petechiae over both lower limbs. She has no history of similar episodes. Laboratory reports revealed thrombocytopenia, anaemia, features of acute kidney injury, and antibodies to ADAMTS13. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a primigravida who presents with sudden onset of fever, neurologic abnormalities(altered mental status, confusion), thrombocytopenia (petechiae over lower limbs), hemolytic anaemia, acute kidney injury and antibodies to  ADAMTS13 suggests the diagnosis of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).  

TTP is a thrombotic microangiopathy that can be inherited or spontaneously acquired. It results from a deficiency of, or antibodies to, the metalloprotease ADAMTS13, which normally cleaves multimers of vWF. Failure to cleave these multimers results in abnormally large vWF multimers which activate platelets and lead to excessive platelet adhesion and aggregation. This causes platelet thrombi to form, and fibrin deposits to take place at various sites. These thrombi result in the classic pentad of clinical features: 

  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Renal failure
  • Neurologic findings
  • Fever

The platelet thrombi narrow the vessel lumen, causing shearing stress on the red blood cells that are passing through. This results in microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia. The same platelet thrombi cause microvascular occlusion and result in features like renal failure and neurological manifestations.

On peripheral smear, these fragmented red cells appear as schistocytes or helmet cells, as shown in the image below:

 

Timely diagnosis is important to prevent devastating outcomes like profuse bleeding and renal failure. The best method to treat these patients is using plasma exchange therapy. It should be continued until the platelet counts are back to normal and there are no signs of hemolysis for at least 2 days. Glucocorticoids can also be used along with this therapy. In refractory cases, rituximab, and caplacizumab an antiVWF nanobody decreases mortality when used in patients with ADAMTS13 <10%.

Other causes of microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia include:

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) (Most common)
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)
  • Malignant hypertension
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Disseminated cancer 

Other options-

Option (A): Immune thrombocytopenic purpura occurs as a chronic disease in adults with several episodes over time, usually following infections. It presents as mucocutaneous bleeding and very low platelet counts. These patients have otherwise normal peripheral blood pictures.

Option (B): Disseminated intravascular coagulation refers to the widespread intravascular clot formation, commonly due to sepsis, trauma, and obstetric complications. These patients present with petechiae, ecchymoses, oozing from venipuncture sites, etc. They do not display the classic pentad seen in TTP. Schistocytes may be present on peripheral smear. Deranged clotting parameters are seen only in DIC and not in TTP.

Option (C): Hemolytic uremic syndrome is a disorder seen predominantly in children, following an episode of bloody diarrhea. Escherichia coli O157:H7 is most commonly the cause of this diarrhea. It can also present with acute renal failure, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia, but neurological manifestations are less common. ADAMTS13 levels are normal in a majority of patients. It can be low in some rare cases.

questions.text: The ECG of a 62-year-old hypertensive patient is given below. What change does the myosin undergo in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given ECG of a hypertensive patient is suggestive of left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH), where the alpha isoform of myosin heavy chain is replaced by the beta isoform. 

The given ECG shows tall left precordial R waves, i.e in the V1 lead, and deep right precordial S waves in the V5 and V6 leads, which are over 35 mm. It also shows the presence of repolarization abnormalities in the form of ST depression with T-wave inversions in the right precordial leads. An increased limb lead voltage (R-aVL) also signifies the presence of left ventricular hypertrophy.

ECG findings suggestive of LVH:

  • S-V1 + R-V5/V6 >35 mm
  • R-aVL + SV3 >20 mm in women and >28 mm in men
  • ST depression with T wave inversion- strain pattern

Causes of LVH:

  • Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Aortic stenosis
  • Aortic regurgitation
  • Mitral regurgitation
  • Coarctation of the aorta
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

Cardiac hypertrophy is associated with a switch in gene expression from genes that encode adult-type contractile proteins to genes that encode distinct fetal isoforms of the same proteins. One such example is where the alpha isoform of myosin heavy chain is replaced by the beta isoform, which has a slower, more energetically economical contraction.

Cardiac hypertrophy is also associated with increased atrial natriuretic factor gene expression. This causes salt secretion by the kidney and decreases blood volume and pressure, thereby reducing hemodynamic load.

Several regressive changes occur in the myocardial fibers when the enlargement of muscle mass is no longer able to cope with the increased burden. They include degradation and loss of myofibrillar contractile elements. In extreme cases, myocyte death can occur. The net result of these changes is cardiac failure.

questions.text: A patient presents with tinnitus and hearing loss. CT of the brain showed a tumor at the cerebellopontine angle. An image from the biopsy is shown below. What does the area marked with an arrow represent?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Verocay bodies, which are found in schwannoma.

Schwannomas are benign tumors that often arise from cranial and peripheral nerves and exhibit Schwann cell differentiation. They can be sporadic or associated with neurofibromatosis-1 (NF1) or occur as vestibular schwannoma (acoustic neuroma) in cases of neurofibromatosis-2 (NF2).

They present with features of nerve compression involving both the adjacent structures and the nerve involved. Most tumors occur in the cranium as acoustic neuromas that affect vestibular branch of VIII cranial nerve near the cerebellopontine angle. They present with tinnitus, hearing loss, and symptoms resulting from compression of the brainstem and cerebellum.

Microscopically, they are comprised of a mixture of dense and loose areas referred to as Antoni A and Antoni B areas, respectively. 

  • Antoni A areas are dense eosinophilic areas containing spindle cells with rod-shaped nuclei lying in the palisading pattern
  • The loose hypocellular Antoni B area contains spindle cells spread apart by the myxoid extracellular matrix.
  • Antoni A area leaves central nuclear-free zones surrounded by the palisading of nuclei, resulting in the formation of structures termed Verocay bodies.


Russell bodies are eosinophilic, homogeneous immunoglobulin-containing cytoplasmic inclusions found in a plasma cell with an excessive synthesis of immunoglobulin. They are seen in multiple myeloma.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with complete obstruction of his left nostril and a nodule on the dorsum of his nose obscuring his vision as shown in the image. He gives a typical history of foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge with crust formation even before this nodule developed. The histology of the biopsied specimen is given as an image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of a nodule on the nose and the given histological image showing Mikulicz cells are suggestive of rhinoscleroma.

Mikulicz cells are large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing the causative bacilli. The history of purulent foul-smelling nasal discharge with crusting before the development of nodules corresponds to the atrophic stage of rhinoscleroma. 

Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus). It has 3 stages:

1. Atrophic stage– Crusting and foul-smelling nasal discharge similar to atrophic rhinitis.

2. Granulomatous stage– Painless, non-ulcerative Granulomatous nodules with subdermal infiltration giving the feel of woody/hebra nose.

3. Cicatricial stage – Fibrosis leading to stenosis of vestibule, pharynx, larynx. The deformity is called a tapir nose.

Treatment: Streptomycin (1g/day) and tetracycline (2g/day) are given together for a period of 4 to 6 weeks. Steroids can be combined with this to reduce fibrosis. Surgical treatment is necessary to restore the airway and correction of the nasal deformity.

Other options:

Option A: Even though the inner canthus of the eye is a common site for the occurrence of basal cell carcinoma, the given histology does not show palisade of the basaloid epithelium, which is very classical of BCC.

Option B: Rhinophyma or potato tumour is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous gland and presents as swelling over tip of the nose.

Option C: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.
